One of the most widely‑reproduced and emotionally powerful statements that helped shift public opinion in the North was **Frederick Douglass’s “What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?”** delivered on **July 5, 1852** at Corinthian Hall in Rochester, New York.  

Below is the opening passage (the part that most often appears in newspapers, pamphlets, and school textbooks) followed by an explanation of why it resonated so strongly with a Northern audience.

---

#### The quotation (first two paragraphs)

> **“What, to the American slave, is your 4th of July?**  
> **I answer: a day that reveals to him, more than all other days in the year, the gross injustice and cruelty to which he is the constant victim.**  
> **It is a day that reveals the gross hypocrisy of a nation which, for eighty‑seven years, has been maintaining an empire of slavery while professing the most lofty ideals of liberty and equality.”**  
> *(Frederick Douglass, “What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?” Rochester, New York, July 5, 1852.)*

> “**You may rejoice, my countrymen, that we have a nation that thinks of liberty and equality; but I cannot rejoice with you.**  
> **Your celebration of independence is a mockery to the millions of men, women, and children who are still chained, sold, and beaten.**  
> **If we are to be truly free, we must first make the whole nation free.”*  

*(The speech continues for nearly an hour; the above excerpt is the most‑quoted portion.)*

---

### Why this passage mattered

| **Aspect** | **How it swayed Northern opinion** |
|------------|--------------------------------------|
| **First‑hand authority** | Douglass was an escaped slave who had become a celebrated orator, writer, and newspaper editor. His lived experience gave his words a credibility that many white reformers could not match. |
| **Moral contrast with national myth** | By juxtaposing the patriotic celebration of **Independence Day** with the reality of slavery, Douglass forced listeners to confront a glaring contradiction in the nation’s self‑image. The rhetorical question “What is the Fourth of July to the slave?” made the hypocrisy impossible to ignore. |
| **Broad circulation** | The speech was printed in **over 30 Northern newspapers** within weeks, re‑printed in abolitionist pamphlets, and later included in Douglass’s own collected works (1881). Its diffusion meant that even people who never heard Douglass speak could read the passage. |
| **Emotional appeal** – *pathos* | Douglass used vivid language (“chains,” “beaten,” “mockery”) that evoked empathy. Contemporary accounts note that audiences in Rochester were moved to tears, and that the speech “stirred the conscience of many who had hitherto been indifferent.” |
| **Political impact** | The speech was cited by **Republican leaders** (e.g., Abraham Lincoln) in debates over the **Kansas–Nebraska Act** and the **Fugitive Slave Law** of 1850. It helped shape the moral platform of the emerging Republican Party, which framed the election of 1860 as a contest over “the future of slavery.” |
| **Legacy** | Historians such as Eric Foner and David Blight rank the speech among the “most influential anti‑slavery texts of the antebellum era.” It is still taught in high‑school curricula as a seminal example of abolitionist rhetoric. |
